history.content:
I've taken this! I really enjoyed it and I think it brings up some really thoughtful case studies and tackles a lot of current day (like this year kind of current) environmental and ethics issues in engineering contexts. CS is not a heavily involved, since the material is focused more on environment and equity issues since it's an AC. The class has a proponent that allows you to work with a community organization; my semester had two projects that involved programming, one for an app that collected air quality data and another involving a water pump for a community garden controlled by a Raspberry Pi. You aren't required to work on a community organization project, but it's a really unique aspect of the class where you can use your work for good! I would recommend reaching out to Khalid Kadir (the instructor) if you want to learn more about the class. 

As for workload, it's not a class that you can just ignore or leave aside to get an A. Khalid gives you all the tools you need to succeed, there are no midterms or exams, and he just expects you to engage with your projects and peers. There's a discussion section once a week, and there are readings every week. Again, there aren't any quizzes, but there are problem sets (pretty easy, done in Jupyter Notebook when I had no Python experience) and reading reflections to do which does take time. I think it's a pretty low-medium workload overall, so viable to take alongside other, more intense classes.

I really enjoyed it and I think it brings up some really thoughtful case studies and tackles a lot of current day (like this year kind of current) environmental and ethics issues in engineering contexts. CS is not a heavily involved, since the material is focused more on environment and equity issues since it's an AC. The class has a proponent that allows you to work with a community organization; my semester had two projects that involved programming, one for an app that collected air quality data and another involving a water pump for a community garden controlled by a Raspberry Pi. You aren't required to work on a community organization project, but it's a really unique aspect of the class where you can use your work for good! I would recommend reaching out to Khalid Kadir (the instructor) if you want to learn more about the class. 

As for workload, it's not a class that you can just ignore or leave aside to get an A. Khalid gives you all the tools you need to succeed, there are no midterms or exams, and he just expects you to engage with your projects and peers. There's a discussion section once a week, and there are readings every week. Again, there aren't any quizzes, but there are problem sets (pretty easy, done in JuniperNotebook when I had no Python experience) and reading reflections to do which does take time. I think it's a pretty low-medium workload overall, so viable to take alongside other, more intense classes.

Has anyone taking Engineering 157AC? It looks super interesting to me. I would love to hear more about what this class is like. How much is the workload alongside an upper div CS course? Will my CS background be relevant in this course or is it largely focused on environmental engineering?
history.subject: E/IAS 157AC
